When they get busted and called on the carpet, they scream that the religion and the Church are being attacked. They work to pull everyone in as the targets, when they are not.  This is how they re stimulate people and use them.</p> <p>Once they can be made aware that they are NOT the targets, (for me anyway), they can be separated out.  There are people out here that are targeting every Scientologist, every Church of Scientology, and every idea Hubbard ever had.  And this is PROOF that everyone and their life and community is under attack and David thrives on this because it gives him cover. But this is a minority.  Most of us do not have animosity towards everybody there and we are not trying to set them up for a loss or run any can&#8217;t have on them. Or even take something away from them. Miscavige frightens them into think they are all being attacked,and they group around him. So he is never forced to stand alone or even, stand out on the front lines.</p> <p>I know exactly how he does it and how he gets away with it.</p> <p>This is a very fragile species that is easily threatened and frightened.  The ones that separate out are the ones that are being enlightened by the people out here.  By information, and kindness. Not by ridicule threats and bullying.</p> <p>SO many people stormed out of that place when Marty offered a HELPING hand. And he has managed,one step at a time,to lay the facts on the table for people to look at.  In the courts,on the Internet and over the phone.  And this is the magic that is working.</p> <p>It does not help people to leave when the Indies and Freezoners are getting attacked out here. A lot of people do not have the ability to walk away from something into nothing.</p> </div>  	</div><!-- #comment-##  -->  	<ul class="children"> 	<li class="comment odd alt depth-5 highlander-comment" id="li-comment-329816"> 		<div id="comment-329816"> 		<div class="comment-author vcard"> 			<img alt='' src='https://1.gravatar.com/avatar/df446e55d540b29e3179a8b84bcee235?s=48&#038;d=identicon&#038;r=G' class='avatar avatar-48' height='48' width='48' /> 			<cite class="fn">Letting go</cite>  			<span class="comment-meta commentmetadata"> 				| 				<a href="https://markrathbun.wordpress.com/2015/02/03/scientology-beliefs/#comment-329816"> 				February 8, 2015 at 6:39 am</a> 					| 					<a class='comment-reply-link' href='/2015/02/03/scientology-beliefs/?replytocom=329816#respond' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-329816", "329816", "respond", "11823" )' aria-label='Reply to Letting go'>Reply</a>								</span><!-- .comment-meta .commentmetadata --> 		</div><!-- .comment-author .vcard --> 		 		<div class="comment-body"><p>Yes, that really makes it very clear to me, both what David Miscavige is doing and the value of the Freezone and Indipendents. When I walked away, it was not into nothing either. I walked a bridge built of a tremendous amount of information and viewpoints to get where I am now, and continue to be extremely grateful to everyone who built that bridge.</p> <p>When I read Dror centre&#8217;s second year report on Mike&#8217;s blog recently, I experienced relief knowing that those people are now completely free to do what they joined scientology to do.</p> </div>  	</div><!-- #comment-##  -->  	</li><!-- #comment-## --> 	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-spyrosillusionist even depth-5 highlander-comment" id="li-comment-330038"> 		<div id="comment-330038"> 		<div class="comment-author vcard"> 			<img alt='' src='https://1.gravatar.com/avatar/1e3a3898eb06ac9bec55d9581e9d1dd4?s=48&#038;d=identicon&#038;r=G' class='avatar avatar-48' height='48' width='48' /> 			<cite class="fn"><a href='http://spyrosillusionist.wordpress.com' rel='external nofollow' class='url'>Spyros</a></cite>  			<span class="comment-meta commentmetadata"> 				| 				<a href="https://markrathbun.wordpress.com/2015/02/03/scientology-beliefs/#comment-330038"> 				February 11, 2015 at 9:41 pm</a> 					| 					<a class='comment-reply-link' href='/2015/02/03/scientology-beliefs/?replytocom=330038#respond' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-330038", "330038", "respond", "11823" )' aria-label='Reply to Spyros'>Reply</a>								</span><!-- .comment-meta .commentmetadata --> 		</div><!-- .comment-author .vcard --> 		 		<div class="comment-body"><p>I think most people that oppose Scientology and people that believe and practice it, don&#8217;t really have anything against each other. The hate is mostly addressed towards some practices that almost anyone would deem to be messed up. But in the process of fighting people tend to generalize, often on purpose, like myself, as I don&#8217;t want to accuse anybody specific in public. And so they go like &#8220;Scientologists are crazy&#8221; etc. I too have said really mean stuff about &#8216;Scientology&#8217; but I had specific things in mind that were indeed really mean. I wouldn&#8217;t do nor recommend to anyone to do that stuff (I have written what that &#8216;stuff&#8217; are, from time to time), of course. But if me or another condemned all &#8216;Scientology&#8217;, he would also condemn much Buddhism, as well as other things that are alligned with Buddhism, and those things are not few. I think what makes Scientology special is it&#8217;s practice -auditing- and the e-meter. Space opera sounds new, but it&#8217;s not completely. It&#8217;s just that the ancient scripts that talk about strange things in the sky, and strange looking creatures, didn&#8217;t use terms such as &#8216;space opera&#8217;, &#8216;aliens&#8217; etc. </p> <p>It is odd that in Scientology there is the concept of the &#8216;third party&#8217; (third party=a person that secretly incites fighting), and is seen as the root of all war, and there is an implication that war is uneccesary and stupid and that fighters are used. I say it is odd, because -based on that- I don&#8217;t see what reasoning one has, if he fights FOR Scientology. As per the text, one should automatically search for a HIDDEN, UNKNOWN third party, if he felt like being drawn into a fight.</p> <p>I do believe it too, that from the division of Scientologists, and critics too, only few could benefit. I can imagine, if somebody wanted to create a sect -to keep people secluded, and in the dark- would benefit from such a war. Those who wouldn&#8217;t want some communications to flow freely. So, they would make communication so painful (fighting) so that people wouldn&#8217;t communicate. I suggest people shouldn&#8217;t play along, and they should take care of each other more, and not divide.</p> </div>  	</div><!-- #comment-##  -->  	<ul class="children"> 	<li class="comment odd alt depth-6 highlander-comment" id="li-comment-330052"> 		<div id="comment-330052"> 		<div class="comment-author vcard"> 			<img alt='' src='https://0.gravatar.com/avatar/350d54331c090bcdace0f231815a0dd3?s=48&#038;d=identicon&#038;r=G' class='avatar avatar-48' height='48' width='48' /> 			<cite class="fn">marildi</cite>  			<span class="comment-meta commentmetadata"> 				| 				<a href="https://markrathbun.wordpress.com/2015/02/03/scientology-beliefs/#comment-330052"> 				February 12, 2015 at 4:37 am</a> 					| 					<a class='comment-reply-link' href='/2015/02/03/scientology-beliefs/?replytocom=330052#respond' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-330052", "330052", "respond", "11823" )' aria-label='Reply to marildi'>Reply</a>								</span><!-- .comment-meta .commentmetadata --> 		</div><!-- .comment-author .vcard --> 		 		<div class="comment-body"><p>Hey Spyros &#8211; you amaze me sometimes. What you wrote is very close to what LRH was saying back in 1955: </p> <p>“…the arduous lesson along this line is that no-communication lists, revocation/suspension of certificates, court action of any kind whatsoever within the realm of Scientology and so forth, is not only…not only difficult to do but does not work. That’s just the end of it. It just doesn’t work. It’s for the sea gulls.</p> <p>“That might work in Gestetner Limited or Westinghouse, but it does not work in Scientology. Got that?</p> <p>“It’s because they are people of good intention. And by saying that these people are not fit to associate with us anymore, we have told a lie of magnitude. This is not true. It’s never true. You got it?</p> <p>“OUR INABILITY TO UNDERSTAND THE ACTIONS OF OTHER SCIENTOLOGISTS HAS A VERY FASCINATING BARRIER. THE LIMITATION ON OUR UNDERSTANDING IS SIMPLY THIS: WE SAY THEY HAVE BAD INTENTIONS, AND THAT IS A LIE. Got it?</p> <p>“So the whole situation is liable to enturbulate around that postulated bad intention. That’s what enturbulates the situation. That makes a lie. The situation then becomes unsolvable. Because we’ve entered a changing factor called a lie into it.</p> <p>“The most valuable asset we have, actually, is our ability to understand, to do the right thing, to be kind, to be decent.</p> <p>“WELL, I HATE TO UNSETTLE A VERY STABLE DATUM, IF IT DOES UNSETTLE IT. BUT THE ONLY WAY ANYTHING EVER DOES RESOLVE IS BY LETTING YOUR OWN KIND HEART REACH THROUGH. THAT’S THE ONLY WAY IT EVER DOES SOLVE. AND IT NEVER SOLVES BY BEING TOUGH.</p> <p>“What do we really have of value in the organizations of Scientology? The only thing we have of value, actually, is Scientology, an understanding of life, increasing ability to communicate, a good concept and grip on reality and the ability to like guys. That’s all you got.</p> <p>“And there’s only one more thing that we could know that would make us all feel very, very relaxed about the whole thing. There isn’t a person anywhere in Scientology who has bad intentions for Scientologists or their fellow man. And that point all by itself is very well worth thinking about the next time some trouble arises in your vicinity, because that is the truth. And if you handle a situation with that in mind, you will solve the situation.”</p> <p>(&#8220;Attitude and Conduct of Scientology”, 4th London ACC, 3rd November 1955)</p> </div>  	</div><!-- #comment-##  -->  	<ul class="children"> 	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-martyrathbun09 comment-author-is-site-member bypostauthor even depth-7 highlander-comment" id="li-comment-330072"> 		<div id="comment-330072"> 		<div class="comment-author vcard"> 			<img alt='' src='https://0.gravatar.com/avatar/c2d94d163a566268e73c8b0195b6c03a?s=48&#038;d=identicon&#038;r=G' class='avatar avatar-48' height='48' width='48' /> 			<cite class="fn">Mark C. Rathbun</cite>  			<span class="comment-meta commentmetadata"> 				| 				<a href="https://markrathbun.wordpress.com/2015/02/03/scientology-beliefs/#comment-330072"> 				February 12, 2015 at 9:19 pm</a> 					| 					<a class='comment-reply-link' href='/2015/02/03/scientology-beliefs/?replytocom=330072#respond' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-330072", "330072", "respond", "11823" )' aria-label='Reply to Mark C. Rathbun'>Reply</a>								</span><!-- .comment-meta .commentmetadata --> 		</div><!-- .comment-author .vcard --> 		 		<div class="comment-body"><p>What&#8217;s amazing is that not only did you buy this hook, line and sinker but that apparently you are going to take all of them to the grave.</p> </div>  	</div><!-- #comment-##  -->  	<ul class="children"> 	<li class="comment odd alt depth-8 highlander-comment" id="li-comment-330440"> 		<div id="comment-330440"> 		<div class="comment-author vcard"> 			<img alt='' src='https://i2.wp.com/graph.facebook.com/v2.2/638982191/picture?q=type%3Dlarge%26_md5%3D7d7a6c4a804508fb5f05b049a1fafd91&#038;resize=48%2C48' class='avatar avatar-48' height='48' width='48' /> 			<cite class="fn"><a href='http://www.facebook.com/638982191' rel='external nofollow' class='url'>Dan Locke</a></cite>  			<span class="comment-meta commentmetadata"> 				| 				<a href="https://markrathbun.wordpress.com/2015/02/03/scientology-beliefs/#comment-330440"> 				February 21, 2015 at 1:19 am</a> 					| 					<a class='comment-reply-link' href='/2015/02/03/scientology-beliefs/?replytocom=330440#respond' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-330440", "330440", "respond", "11823" )' aria-label='Reply to Dan Locke'>Reply</a>								</span><!-- .comment-meta .commentmetadata --> 		</div><!-- .comment-author .vcard --> 		 		<div class="comment-body"><p>Lots of people bought that hook line and sinker, Marty, because that was what we thought was the proper attitude and conduct of Scientology and Scientologists &#8212; even as we were being hounded and berated at the service org level and as you guys were pummeling each other at Int. </p> <p>I think if you looked a little further and purposefully looked for other points of view you&#8217;d see that many Scientologists never bought into these things you have mislabeled as the &#8220;core beliefs&#8221; of Scientology. These aren&#8217;t core beliefs at all, and to say that they are is just sloppy thinking and I am surprised to see you thinking that way. </p> <p>Your points are not the core beliefs of Scientology; they are the peripheral delusions of L. Ron Hubbard and many of them were slipped into the bulletins and policy letters and lectures and there have been SOME who believed them &#8211; not many, but some. </p> <p>There have never been millions of Scientologists, but I&#8217;d bet that there have been some hundreds of thousands who at one time or another proudly considered themselves to be Scientologists or Dianeticists and yet had subscribed to little or none of these &#8220;core beliefs&#8221;. </p> <p>The things you are calling the core beliefs of Scientology were never the core beliefs of most of the people who have directly benefited from Scientology. These are the beliefs of some staff members and some Sea Org members and the most zealous of public. But that&#8217;s a minority of the people who have been or are involved. </p> <p>What&#8217;s the average tenure of a staff member? It is much less than two and a half years &#8211; very few complete a contract. What&#8217;s the average tenure of a Sea Org member? I don&#8217;t think much longer. You accept that sort of thinking when you are in as it&#8217;s part of the battle-cry and part of the game the way Ron had it mocked up. Ron admits to needing enemies. There&#8217;s at least one place where he admits to it being his decision to make the psychs the bad guys. We all had to band together to fight to coalesce the group. It&#8217;s like the sci fi stories of all the nations of earth getting their shit together to beat the mean martians.</p> <p>But once you leave staff, you don&#8217;t have to put up with that harangue anymore. When you leave Truman&#8217;s World and you realize it, you know longer have to act like Jim Carey. </p> <p>What percentage of people who get involved finally arrive onto OT 3? Very small. What&#8217;s the percentage of OT 3s who quit very soon after? I understand it&#8217;s pretty high. People blow off those levels as Ron&#8217;s Sci Fi explanation of the problems of the universe just doesn&#8217;t make for very good reasoning. It&#8217;s hard to stomach as a &#8220;right why&#8221; for the travails of Man. </p> <p>I think most Scientologists when we knew of these beliefs did not buy into them. Maybe the psychiatrist one a bit, as there certainly was evidence that these people certainly had a bloody history. </p> <p>Yes, they cheer as long as they are in and nod their heads in agreement, but once they are out, these ideas you have mentioned, if they were ever believed are soon jettisoned as they just don&#8217;t make sense.  Believing in such things when you are not on staff is just not a component in building a better life. </p> <p>You have done a good job of identifying LRH&#8217;s fantastically ridiculous notions about the world that he did his best to get people to accept as true. But this particular bit of hypnotism was not successful to most Scientologists. To label them as &#8220;core beliefs&#8221;: just not so. </p> <p>These might be considered the core beliefs of the most nutty people in Scientology, or of many Scientologists when they were at their most nutty, but these are not the core beliefs of Scientology or most Scientologists. </p> <p>Henry Ford did much to advance the technology of management. He also had a lot of screwball notions, not about psychs, but pretty much the same sort of thinking about Jews. In Spring 1920, Ford made his personal newspaper, The Dearborn Independent, chronicle what he considered the &#8220;Jewish menace&#8221;. Every week for 91 issues, the paper exposed some sort of Jewish-inspired evil major story in a headline. </p> <p>Undoubtedly lots of people believed just as he did and cheered him on. But there were also thousands if not millions who said, &#8220;Makes a great car, but what a creep!&#8221;</p> <p>You can&#8217;t truthfully say that Ford&#8217;s perverse view of the world made his management technology looney. People in his camp were able to differentiate. The same is true with many Scientologists.</p> <p>The true core beliefs for most people who have ever been Scientologists are truly the Scientology Zero materials and the Creed and the Aims. Yes, pretty much all the things grandma would agree to if they were well explained. These are the true core beliefs. </p> <p>The things you mentioned aren&#8217;t core; they are strategies that LRH put into place to frighten people into compliance, and, being that they were in direct opposition to the core things that were taught that really did align with &#8220;the combined truths of fifty thousand years of thinking men&#8221;, they never worked very well for very long. </p> <p>Every time one reads about the &#8220;good old days&#8221; of Scientology, they are talking about their times in a mission or org where ARC and the best things of life were the way the game was played.  Truly there are many of us who will indeed carry the points of view given in &#8220;Attitude and Conduct of Scientologists&#8221; to our graves.</p> <p>And wherever did you get the information where you could say &#8220;<i><b>In fact</b></i> scientology never achieved even the scientifically recognized 20 to 30 percent placebo effect in terms of long-term satisfaction.&#8221;? I am very curious about what data you or someone has that brought about that conclusion. I venture to say that there are no actual facts that back up that conclusion, or that these &#8220;facts&#8221; were advanced by a very prejudiced individual.</p> </div>  	</div><!-- #comment-##  -->  	<ul class="children"> 	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-martyrathbun09 comment-author-is-site-member bypostauthor even depth-9 highlander-comment" id="li-comment-330451"> 		<div id="comment-330451"> 		<div class="comment-author vcard"> 			<img alt='' src='https://0.gravatar.com/avatar/c2d94d163a566268e73c8b0195b6c03a?s=48&#038;d=identicon&#038;r=G' class='avatar avatar-48' height='48' width='48' /> 			<cite class="fn">Mark C. Rathbun</cite>  			<span class="comment-meta commentmetadata"> 				| 				<a href="https://markrathbun.wordpress.com/2015/02/03/scientology-beliefs/#comment-330451"> 				February 21, 2015 at 12:14 pm</a> 					| 					<a class='comment-reply-link' href='/2015/02/03/scientology-beliefs/?replytocom=330451#respond' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-330451", "330451", "respond", "11823" )' aria-label='Reply to Mark C. What you note as &#8216;core beliefs&#8217; are unoriginal secular, positive thinking pablum.  They are of the hook referenced in core religious belief number 1.  As to the placebo effect numbers provenance, it is 35 years of observation and experience &#8211; with thorough access to scientology&#8217;s religiously implanted obsession with statistics &#8211; with the subject in and out of the organization.  Only a very hypnotized, dramatizing (continuing to mock it up wildly) scientologist would counter with the idea such facts are the invention of a &#8216;very prejudiced individual.&#8217;  I will say (concede) this for your comment, it indicates that you are quite the sincere, compliant religious adherent to this day.</p> </div>  	</div><!-- #comment-##  -->  	<ul class="children"> 	<li vinaire'>Reply</a>								</span><!-- .comment-meta .commentmetadata --> 		</div><!-- .comment-author .vcard --> 		 		<div class="comment-body"><p>I think that &#8220;Scientology&#8221; as a brand of knowledge is finished because of the way it presented itself to the general public, and how it has acted as an organized religion. It is no use trying to defend this brand.</p> <p>As far as knowledge is concerned, it flowed into Scientology and it has flowed out. What is good and useful shall continue to be appreciated. What is bad and evil shall targetd until it is disposed of.</p> <p>Any love affair with the brand called &#8220;Scientology&#8221; is nothing but hypnotic attachment. </p> <p>It is better to focus on knowledge and to let go of Scientology.</p> </div>  	</div><!-- #comment-##  -->  	</li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- But I am idealistic too, until some &#8216;superior&#8217; dude comes at work and with a bitter face, and finds everything about me and my workplace wrong and guilty and demands that I do much more than I&#8217;m supposed to, to serve him, like he was my master. or else he will write bad reviews about me and my workplace on the internet, hoping I will lose -or be afraid I will lose- my job. And he comes in and causes much more trouble to us the staff and the customers, and demands much more pampering than anybody.</p> <p>If the workplace was mine, I&#8217;d kindly -or not- show him the way out. If we are so bad, what are you doing here, anyway? I think. Or I try to not think. But the workplaces owners want the money, so I&#8217;m not allowed to do that. </p> <p>I think to consider that such guys are not really bad, but rather mad, thinking their life depends upon others death, is a kind compliment. </p> <p>Still, I take it further wondering how come I draw such stuff to me. Is it random or?</p> <p>Anyway, it&#8217;s nice and easy to be idealistic from a distance. And maybe a good solution would for people to play the games (including jobs) that they want to play. Maybe it is indeed my fault, if I don&#8217;t.</p> </div>  	</div><!-- #comment-##  -->  	<ul class="children"> 	<li class="comment even depth-10 highlander-comment" id="li-comment-330139"> 		<div id="comment-330139"> 		<div class="comment-author vcard"> 			<img alt='' src='https://0.gravatar.com/avatar/350d54331c090bcdace0f231815a0dd3?s=48&#038;d=identicon&#038;r=G' class='avatar avatar-48' height='48' width='48' /> 			<cite class="fn">marildi</cite>  			<span class="comment-meta commentmetadata"> 				| 				<a href="https://markrathbun.wordpress.com/2015/02/03/scientology-beliefs/#comment-330139"> 				February 14, 2015 at 5:38 pm</a> 					| 													</span><!-- .comment-meta .commentmetadata --> 		</div><!-- .comment-author .vcard --> 		 		<div class="comment-body"><p>Yep, that&#8217;s the idealistic Spyros I&#8217;ve come to know and admire. <span class='wp-smiley wp-emoji wp-emoji-tongue' title=':P'>:P</span></p> <p>To answer your unvoiced question, I could say to you to &#8220;handle or disconnect&#8221;  (and play the game you love!). But I&#8217;m sure you know just as much about that tech as I do &#8211; so I&#8217;m guessing that with either of those choices, it&#8217;s &#8220;easier said than done.&#8221; </p> <p>You brought up another possibly relevant point &#8211; &#8220;how come I draw such stuff to me&#8221;. In Buddhism, I suppose the answer would be &#8220;karma&#8221;, and of course there are Buddhist practices to &#8220;handle&#8221;.  In scientology, the answer is similar &#8211; &#8220;O/W&#8217;s&#8221; &#8211; with one solution being to write them up. Another scn solution would be TR-0, which all in itself could possibly even make a change in that other guy &#8211; or maybe just in yourself. </p> <p>Well, guess what &#8211; I&#8217;ve got another Eckhart Tolle vid for you, which I would say is really just another way of describing TR-0, but maybe he communicates it better for some people. Take it as my little Valentine&#8217;s Day &#8220;card&#8221; for you. <span class='wp-smiley wp-emoji wp-emoji-heart' title='&lt;3'>&lt;3</span> <span class='wp-smiley wp-emoji wp-emoji-tongue' title=':P'>:P</span></p> <p><span class='embed-youtube' style='text-align:center; display: block;'><iframe class='youtube-player' type='text/html' width='500' height='312' src='https://www.youtube.com/embed/rvXbou16ziA?version=3&#038;rel=1&#038;fs=1&#038;showsearch=0&#038;showinfo=1&#038;iv_load_policy=1&#038;wmode=transparent' frameborder='0' allowfullscreen='true'></iframe></span></p> </div>  	</div><!-- #comment-##  -->  	</li><!-- #comment-## --> 	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-spyrosillusionist odd alt depth-10 highlander-comment" id="li-comment-330168"> 		<div id="comment-330168"> 		<div class="comment-author vcard"> 			<img alt='' src='https://1.gravatar.com/avatar/1e3a3898eb06ac9bec55d9581e9d1dd4?s=48&#038;d=identicon&#038;r=G' class='avatar avatar-48' height='48' width='48' /> 			<cite class="fn"><a href='http://spyrosillusionist.wordpress.com' rel='external nofollow' class='url'>Spyros</a></cite>  			<span class="comment-meta commentmetadata"> 				| 				<a href="https://markrathbun.wordpress.com/2015/02/03/scientology-beliefs/#comment-330168"> 				February 16, 2015 at 1:26 am</a> 					| 													</span><!-- .comment-meta .commentmetadata --> 		</div><!-- .comment-author .vcard --> 		 		<div class="comment-body"><p>Well, I no longer use any techniques. Anyone who wants, can use them. I know what I should do with myself now, to deal with my issues. </p> <p>If you&#8217;re interested in LRH&#8217;s opinion about karma and O/Ws, as opposed to what I was told, you can check out HCOB &#8216;O/Ws a limited theory&#8217;.</p> <p>Thanx for the gift <span class='wp-smiley wp-emoji wp-emoji-smile' title=':)'>:)</span></p> </div>  	</div><!-- #comment-##  -->  	</li><!-- #comment-## --> 	<li class="comment even depth-10 highlander-comment" id="li-comment-330185"> 		<div id="comment-330185"> 		<div class="comment-author vcard"> 			<img alt='' src='https://0.gravatar.com/avatar/350d54331c090bcdace0f231815a0dd3?s=48&#038;d=identicon&#038;r=G' class='avatar avatar-48' height='48' width='48' /> 			<cite class="fn">marildi</cite>  			<span class="comment-meta commentmetadata"> 				| 				<a href="https://markrathbun.wordpress.com/2015/02/03/scientology-beliefs/#comment-330185"> 				February 16, 2015 at 9:43 pm</a> 					| 													</span><!-- .comment-meta .commentmetadata --> 		</div><!-- .comment-author .vcard --> 		 		<div class="comment-body"><p>Spyros: &#8220;I know what I should do with myself now, to deal with my issues.&#8221;</p> <p>Good to know you&#8217;re back in character. <span class='wp-smiley wp-emoji wp-emoji-smile' title=':)'>:)</span></p> <p>Did you watch that vid (it&#8217;s only 4 minutes)? I loved it that Tolle used Obama (I had you in good company!) as an example of someone who remains &#8220;conscious&#8221; in spite of all the heavy stuff he deals with. He then questioned (this was a few years ago) whether even Obama would continue to withstand all the &#8220;unconscious&#8221; beings he is confronted with.</p> <p>Thanks for reminding me about that bulletin &#8220;O/W, A Limited Theory&#8221;! I am familiar with it (read it first on Level II) but wasn&#8217;t keeping it in mind &#8211; and it should be. It has some valuable data:</p> <p>&#8220;Before I would permit you to believe that the overt-withhold mechanism was a total way of life, I would point out that it applies only to a strata of existence and that it stems from failures to help&#8230;.</p> <p>&#8220;O/W is a theory which sets in when aberration sets in. It is not a high natural law. It is junior to the various laws of Communication, Control and Help.</p> <p>&#8220;O/W can occur only when help has failed. Help is a co-joining of vectors of life.</p> <p>&#8220;When two beings who have joined forces to help fail each other, only then does O/W come into existence.&#8221;</p> </div>  	</div><!-- #comment-##  -->  	</li><!-- #comment-## --> 	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-spyrosillusionist odd alt depth-10 highlander-comment" id="li-comment-330197"> 		<div id="comment-330197"> 		<div class="comment-author vcard"> 			<img alt='' src='https://1.gravatar.com/avatar/1e3a3898eb06ac9bec55d9581e9d1dd4?s=48&#038;d=identicon&#038;r=G' class='avatar avatar-48' height='48' width='48' /> 			<cite class="fn"><a href='http://spyrosillusionist.wordpress.com' rel='external nofollow' class='url'>Spyros</a></cite>  			<span class="comment-meta commentmetadata"> 				| 				<a href="https://markrathbun.wordpress.com/2015/02/03/scientology-beliefs/#comment-330197"> 				February 17, 2015 at 12:54 am</a> 					| 													</span><!-- .comment-meta .commentmetadata --> 		</div><!-- .comment-author .vcard --> 		 		<div class="comment-body"><p>I didn&#8217;t want to get into that again, so as not to sound mean, and just let it be, but since you ask me again, I will say it again. I think TRs are good Div 6 stuff, and drills for auditors. But they could as well be nicely used in psychology &#8211;the way I have done those TRs. And they are not spirituality. Particularly, this not reacting thing, this poker face,  is well taught in psychosciences too, and is considered a desirable EP. Like Hubbard wrote in the book about the purif RD &#8216;We used to have men made of iron and ships men of wood and now we have ships made of iron and men made of wood&#8217;. I don&#8217;t like TRs and the fixation on body PT. TRs so as to go through difficulties in communicating, yes. TRs to make you wood, no. Before you tell me how Hubbard wrote about robotic TRs and premature acks, I know about it. And may I also tell you how I have mostly witnessed that, and not anything else, and how TRs ARC broke me constantly, because they seemed fake to me, and I didn&#8217;t feel I communicated at all. Of course it was my fault because &#8216;I had too many witholds&#8217;. Bah. How come I no longer ARC break? Maybe I had something with SCN eh? Nope. the SCN group had something with itself. The other fixation on flow 1 omits the other 3 flows, and it&#8217;s done on purpose to implant guilts, by the way. Nobody questions the group. It&#8217;s all your fault mehehe. Guess what, that&#8217;s blame from the group to the person too! </p> <p>Yes, I watched the video, but I&#8217;m still not sure whether he has something in mind like the TRs I mentioned, or something else. Obama projects the iimage Tolle says, indeed. Who knows what goes on  inside him? A capable person could project about anything. I&#8217;m not implying anything. I just don&#8217;t know Obama. I only know a face I see on tv.<br />  <span class='wp-smiley wp-emoji wp-emoji-smile' title=':)'>:)</span></p> </div>  	</div><!-- #comment-##  -->  	</li><!-- #comment-## --> 	<li class="comment even depth-10 highlander-comment" id="li-comment-330242"> 		<div id="comment-330242"> 		<div class="comment-author vcard"> 			<img alt='' src='https://0.gravatar.com/avatar/350d54331c090bcdace0f231815a0dd3?s=48&#038;d=identicon&#038;r=G' class='avatar avatar-48' height='48' width='48' /> 			<cite class="fn">marildi</cite>  			<span class="comment-meta commentmetadata"> 				| 				<a href="https://markrathbun.wordpress.com/2015/02/03/scientology-beliefs/#comment-330242"> 				February 17, 2015 at 5:40 pm</a> 					| 													</span><!-- .comment-meta .commentmetadata --> 		</div><!-- .comment-author .vcard --> 		 		<div class="comment-body"><p>Spyros: “…And may I also tell you how I have mostly witnessed that, and not anything else, and how TRs ARC broke me constantly, because they seemed fake to me, and I didn’t feel I communicated at all… Maybe I had something with SCN eh? The most important point I have explained, is that TRs are &#8216;too much body&#8217;, the way I see them. They are communication drills, not meditation. I don&#8217;t see how they relate to what I said about attempts to get me bullied. There is more, for me, than dealing more efficiently with a problem, and that is not having it. And the &#8216;handle or disconnect&#8217; is a choice similar to &#8216;get a job or not&#8217;, if you don&#8217;t control who you communicate with at your job. Of course, I only talk whenever and with whomever I want to, whenever I think I have a choice. It doesn&#8217;t matter whether I think &#8216;SP&#8217; or not.</p> <p>I can imagine TRs and other things being used in a self determined manner. But I didn&#8217;t take it there in the first place &#8211;whether LRH meant them to be like that or not. I have pounded that a bit too much, and I think it&#8217;s best for each one to find out for himself, like the poem says. I only talk general philosophy, for the sake for each person&#8217;s personal gains, SCN or not. I don&#8217;t want to antagonize anymore whether SCN is right or wrong. I might talk about TRs like I would talk about Tolle&#8217;s ideas.</p> <p>I am reluctant to defend Scientology, for the same reason I asked that rhetorical question about DM. For it doesn&#8217;t matter as much, in practice, what LRH intended, but it mostly matters what happens in the name of LRH. If I wanted to defend SCN, I would consider people that mess SCNists from inside, more harmful than people that antagonize SCN from the outside. It&#8217;s the same coin, but different sides. I try to go with the golden line.</p> <p>My stay in SCN was &#8217;98-&#8217;04, I think, and that was the duration of my doing TRs, as they were plenty.</p> </div>  	</div><!-- #comment-##  -->  	</li><!-- #comment-## --> 	<li class="comment even depth-10 highlander-comment" id="li-comment-330311"> 		<div id="comment-330311"> 		<div class="comment-author vcard"> 			<img alt='' src='https://0.gravatar.com/avatar/350d54331c090bcdace0f231815a0dd3?s=48&#038;d=identicon&#038;r=G' class='avatar avatar-48' height='48' width='48' /> 			<cite class="fn">marildi</cite>  			<span class="comment-meta commentmetadata"> 				| 				<a href="https://markrathbun.wordpress.com/2015/02/03/scientology-beliefs/#comment-330311"> 				February 19, 2015 at 1:16 am</a> 					| 													</span><!-- .comment-meta .commentmetadata --> 		</div><!-- .comment-author .vcard --> 		 		<div class="comment-body"><p>SP (I&#8217;ll just use your initials &#8211; joke! <span class='wp-smiley wp-emoji wp-emoji-bigsmile' title=':D'>:D</span> ): &#8220;TRs are ‘too much body’, the way I see them. They are communication drills, not meditation.&#8221;</p> <p>That&#8217;s all they&#8217;re supposed to be &#8211; communication drills &#8211; their primary purpose. However, to me, OT-TR-0 and TR-0 are types of meditation (there are many types), not unlike what Eckhart Tolle describes.  </p> <p>&#8220;I don’t see how they relate to what I said about attempts to get me bullied.&#8221; </p> <p>TRs may not relate to every bully situation &#8211; depending on the bully. But I&#8217;m sure many people could attest to having handled some bully&#8217;s attitude simply by being there comfortably. Or maybe by giving him a really good ack, as another example.</p> <p>The interesting thing about TRs, and everything else in scientology, is that everyone can benefit at a level that suits wherever they happen to be as a being &#8211; if the tech is in, that is. What happened to you makes me wonder if the situation was similar to this quote from an early edition of NSOL, in an essay about Acceptance Level:</p> <p>&#8220;You can understand, too, some of you, why you were not acceptable in your own homes when you were young; you were too bright and too cheerful and this was too high above those around you.&#8221;</p> <p>You wrote: &#8220;I might talk about TRs like I would talk about Tolle’s ideas.&#8221;</p> <p>That&#8217;s really how I feel too (contrary to popular belief <span class='wp-smiley wp-emoji wp-emoji-smile' title=':)'>:)</span> ). But not everybody is willing to talk about some particular part of scientology in and of itself, separate from other parts. That&#8217;s one reason I like to talk to you, and a few others, because I know that you can have a straight comm cycle with me &#8211; and that you aren&#8217;t unwilling to say something good about scn. Or something bad, for that matter (with good TRs! <span class='wp-smiley wp-emoji wp-emoji-tongue' title=':P'>:P</span> ). You summed it up beautifully here:</p> <p>&#8220;For it doesn’t matter as much, in practice, what LRH intended, but it mostly matters what happens in the name of LRH.&#8221;</p> <p>&#8220;98-&#8217;04&#8243;? Well, no doubt there were &#8220;additives&#8221; on your course, especially since that was after GAT in &#8217;96. Too bad you never got a TR&#8217;s Correction List after that &#8211; by someone whose TRs were in! <span class='wp-smiley wp-emoji wp-emoji-wink' title=';)'>;)</span></p> </div>  	</div><!-- #comment-##  -->  	</li><!-- #comment-## --> 	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-spyrosillusionist odd alt depth-10 highlander-comment" id="li-comment-330335"> 		<div id="comment-330335"> 		<div class="comment-author vcard"> 			<img alt='' src='https://1.gravatar.com/avatar/1e3a3898eb06ac9bec55d9581e9d1dd4?s=48&#038;d=identicon&#038;r=G' class='avatar avatar-48' height='48' width='48' /> 			<cite class="fn"><a href='http://spyrosillusionist.wordpress.com' rel='external nofollow' class='url'>Spyros</a></cite>  			<span class="comment-meta commentmetadata"> 				| 				<a href="https://markrathbun.wordpress.com/2015/02/03/scientology-beliefs/#comment-330335"> 				February 19, 2015 at 9:41 am</a> 					| 													</span><!-- .comment-meta .commentmetadata --> 		</div><!-- .comment-author .vcard --> 		 		<div class="comment-body"><p>I admit what I said that TRs are not meditation, is a bit off, because there are body meditations too. </p> <p>There can come a time when you no longer have to have some phenomena and to go back to handle them, convinced that you still have them, just because you CAN have them. That would be &#8216;black&#8217;, the way I see it. That&#8217;s what I have against &#8216;TRs all the way&#8217; or &#8216;Clears are not really Clear&#8217; and stuff like that. That can go on forever, creating charge and discharging it (or not). It is black to point out that somebody has something that he doesn&#8217;t know he has, as from then on he might as well start to create it. It is an alteration, and it can put a person to create case. If SCN was the only thing that puts people to create case, I would agree with Marty in all he says.  But psychology/psychiatry do a fine job telling people that they have things they didn&#8217;t know, they had, no? </p> </div>  	</div><!-- #comment-##  -->  	</li><!-- #comment-## --> 	<li class="comment even depth-10 highlander-comment" id="li-comment-330360"> 		<div id="comment-330360"> 		<div class="comment-author vcard"> 			<img alt='' src='https://0.gravatar.com/avatar/350d54331c090bcdace0f231815a0dd3?s=48&#038;d=identicon&#038;r=G' class='avatar avatar-48' height='48' width='48' /> 			<cite class="fn">marildi</cite>  			<span class="comment-meta commentmetadata"> 				| 				<a href="https://markrathbun.wordpress.com/2015/02/03/scientology-beliefs/#comment-330360"> 				February 19, 2015 at 10:28 pm</a> 					| 													</span><!-- .comment-meta .commentmetadata --> 		</div><!-- .comment-author .vcard --> 		 		<div class="comment-body"><p>Spyros, maybe not the other TRs but I don&#8217;t think  OT-TR0 could be called a body meditation. It could be as simple as to tell somebody that &#8216;you are stupid&#8217;, if he believes you. You know, you can put him to put it there, afterwards, by making him resist it, try to handle it etc &#8211;further alteration.  It&#8217;s common for people to tell each other &#8216;you are this and that&#8217;. It doesn&#8217;t take a professional. But it isn&#8217;t the truth.</p> </div>  	</div><!-- #comment-##  -->  	</li><!-- #comment-## --> 	<li class="comment odd alt depth-10 highlander-comment" id="li-comment-330362"> 		<div id="comment-330362"> 		<div class="comment-author vcard"> 			<img alt='' src='https://0.gravatar.com/avatar/350d54331c090bcdace0f231815a0dd3?s=48&#038;d=identicon&#038;r=G' class='avatar avatar-48' height='48' width='48' /> 			<cite class="fn">marildi</cite>  			<span class="comment-meta commentmetadata"> 				| 				<a href="https://markrathbun.wordpress.com/2015/02/03/scientology-beliefs/#comment-330362"> 				February 19, 2015 at 10:41 pm</a> 					| 													</span><!-- .comment-meta .commentmetadata --> 		</div><!-- .comment-author .vcard --> 		 		<div class="comment-body"><p>Totally got it, Spy. <span class='wp-smiley wp-emoji wp-emoji-smile' title=':)'>:)</span></p> <p> And on top of that is the view expressed in the following quote, which you might appreciate (note &#8211; “Basic Truth” is defined in Axiom 35 as “a Static”):</p> <p>“It seems that the ‘only’ [as in “the only one”] aberration can occur by enforcing Basic Truth. Here we discover that the individual, being separate, is then FORCED to be separate, and so develops a complex of ‘the only one’ and tries to fend off the rest of the universe from himself and finally merges with it with his impossibility of fending it off. ALL YOU HAVE TO DO IS ACCENTUATE TRUTH AND FORCE IT HOME as an Other-determinism IN ORDER TO CREATE AN ABERRATION. There is some Basic Truth, then, in whatever is wrong with a thetan… [my caps for emphasis]”</p> <p>Isn&#8217;t that interesting? That there is &#8220;some Basic Truth&#8221; in any aberration? This would have to be the case before you could have a duality that hangs you up.</p> </div>  	</div><!-- #comment-##  -->  	</li><!-- #comment-## --> 	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-spyrosillusionist even depth-10 highlander-comment" id="li-comment-330397"> 		<div id="comment-330397"> 		<div class="comment-author vcard"> 			<img alt='' src='https://1.gravatar.com/avatar/1e3a3898eb06ac9bec55d9581e9d1dd4?s=48&#038;d=identicon&#038;r=G' class='avatar avatar-48' height='48' width='48' /> 			<cite class="fn"><a href='http://spyrosillusionist.wordpress.com' rel='external nofollow' class='url'>Spyros</a></cite>  			<span class="comment-meta commentmetadata"> 				| 				<a href="https://markrathbun.wordpress.com/2015/02/03/scientology-beliefs/#comment-330397"> 				February 20, 2015 at 12:34 pm</a> 					| 													</span><!-- .comment-meta .commentmetadata --> 		</div><!-- .comment-author .vcard --> 		 		<div class="comment-body"><p>Yes Marildi. Every + and every &#8211; have a portion of truth. And as long as there are poles, there are also lies. And as one seeks truth he might find supporting truth along with lies, or opposing lies along with truth. And lies get supported and truth gets hit, and war doesn&#8217;t work.</p> <p>Thus,  I don&#8217;t want to argue about TRs etc anymore. But I read an interesting poem recently. The language is a bit difficult, but it&#8217;s worthy. It&#8217;s much about all that we talk about in here.</p> <p><a href="http://philoctetes.free.fr/parmenidesunicode.htm" rel="nofollow">http://philoctetes.free.fr/parmenidesunicode.htm</a> </p> </div>  	</div><!-- #comment-##  -->  	</li><!-- #comment-## --> 	<li class="comment odd alt depth-10 highlander-comment" id="li-comment-330439"> 		<div id="comment-330439"> 		<div class="comment-author vcard"> 			<img alt='' src='https://0.gravatar.com/avatar/350d54331c090bcdace0f231815a0dd3?s=48&#038;d=identicon&#038;r=G' class='avatar avatar-48' height='48' width='48' /> 			<cite class="fn">marildi</cite>  			<span class="comment-meta commentmetadata"> 				| 				<a href="https://markrathbun.wordpress.com/2015/02/03/scientology-beliefs/#comment-330439"> 				February 21, 2015 at 1:05 am</a> 					| 													</span><!-- .comment-meta .commentmetadata --> 		</div><!-- .comment-author .vcard --> 		 		<div class="comment-body"><p>Spyros, thanks for posting the poem of Parmenides. I&#8217;m surprised that you only read that recently, because it comes across as your way of thinking and expressing yourself &#8211; your &#8220;style&#8221;.  Reading along, I started to wonder if Parmenides was your direct ancestor and that you inherited his DNA!</p> <p>As for what you said regarding &#8220;arguing about TRs, etc.&#8221;, what I think is that former scientologists seem to have a common bond &#8211; probably because most of us are seekers of truth. So, to me, it&#8217;s kind of a shame that we aren&#8217;t free enough with/from scientology that we can have free and open discussions about it. This is the common subject among us, and it could easily be used as a springboard and &#8220;datum of comparable magnitude&#8221; to so many other topics of discussion.</p> <p>As an example, on the subject of DNA, have you heard or read anything about &#8220;spiritual DNA&#8221;? Here&#8217;s a less than 5-minute vid that gives an overview:</p> <p><span class='embed-youtube' style='text-align:center; display: block;'><iframe class='youtube-player' type='text/html' width='500' height='312' src='https://www.youtube.com/embed/r_cBKkY48H4?version=3&#038;rel=1&#038;fs=1&#038;showsearch=0&#038;showinfo=1&#038;iv_load_policy=1&#038;wmode=transparent' frameborder='0' allowfullscreen='true'></iframe></span></p> </div>  	</div><!-- #comment-##  -->  	</li><!-- #comment-## --> 	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-iamvalkov even depth-10 highlander-comment" id="li-comment-330270"> 		<div id="comment-330270"> 		<div class="comment-author vcard"> 			<img alt='' src='https://1.gravatar.com/avatar/742817c1603c6e5f9f5086f4763a57b5?s=48&#038;d=identicon&#038;r=G' class='avatar avatar-48' height='48' width='48' /> 			<cite class="fn"><a href='http://valkovuddin.wordpress.com' rel='external nofollow' class='url'>iamvalkov</a></cite>  			<span class="comment-meta commentmetadata"> 				| 				<a href="https://markrathbun.wordpress.com/2015/02/03/scientology-beliefs/#comment-330270"> 				February 17, 2015 at 8:58 pm</a> 					| 													</span><!-- .comment-meta .commentmetadata --> 		</div><!-- .comment-author .vcard --> 		 		<div class="comment-body"><p>TRs are supposed to be natural. I made a vid where my &#8220;pc&#8221; (coach) went into grief, and I just naturally lowered my tone level too. The Sup was reluctant to send it up because she had the idea that auditors should always be uptone, but she sent it anyway stating her reservations. The Senior C/S sent it back with a &#8220;Pass&#8221; and wrote, &#8220;She was in ARC with the pc.&#8221; By the time the late &#8217;90&#8217;s came along and everybody had to do all the courses over again because of GAT in &#8217;96, &#8220;natural TRs&#8221; became very confusing for a lot of us.</p> </div>  	</div><!-- #comment-##  -->  	</li><!-- #comment-## --> 	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-spyrosillusionist odd alt depth-10 highlander-comment" id="li-comment-330198"> 		<div id="comment-330198"> 		<div class="comment-author vcard"> 			<img alt='' src='https://1.gravatar.com/avatar/1e3a3898eb06ac9bec55d9581e9d1dd4?s=48&#038;d=identicon&#038;r=G' class='avatar avatar-48' height='48' width='48' /> 			<cite class="fn"><a href='http://spyrosillusionist.wordpress.com' rel='external nofollow' class='url'>Spyros</a></cite>  			<span class="comment-meta commentmetadata"> 				| 				<a href="https://markrathbun.wordpress.com/2015/02/03/scientology-beliefs/#comment-330198"> 				February 17, 2015 at 1:02 am</a> 					| 													</span><!-- .comment-meta .commentmetadata --> 		</div><!-- .comment-author .vcard --> 		 		<div class="comment-body"><p>*flow 2, not flow 1. I meant fixation on O/Ws.</p> </div>  	</div><!-- #comment-##  -->  	</li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## --> 	<li class="comment even depth-7 highlander-comment" id="li-comment-330106"> 		<div id="comment-330106"> 		<div class="comment-author vcard"> 			<img alt='' src='https://0.gravatar.com/avatar/f4dd23d6f380e5693407c8da3aed3807?s=48&#038;d=identicon&#038;r=G' class='avatar avatar-48' height='48' width='48' /> 			<cite class="fn">MarkNR</cite>  			<span class="comment-meta commentmetadata"> 				| 				<a href="https://markrathbun.wordpress.com/2015/02/03/scientology-beliefs/#comment-330106"> 				February 13, 2015 at 11:04 pm</a> 					| 					<a class='comment-reply-link' href='/2015/02/03/scientology-beliefs/?replytocom=330106#respond' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-330106", "330106", "respond", "11823" )' aria-label='Reply to MarkNR'>Reply</a>								</span><!-- .comment-meta .commentmetadata --> 		</div><!-- .comment-author .vcard --> 		 		<div class="comment-body"><p>Mr. Hubbard was quite a complex man.  Rich with love and compassion for his fellows.  You and I.  Driven to help man and mankind.  Obsessed to find the properties of life and living.  Plagued with demons and attackers, fanatically protecting his work.  Amazing powers of observation, insight, vision.  The ability to work, nonstop, for years if necessary to find the cause and solution for an outpoint.  He also had quite a talent for gathering and sifting through information, codifying it, and making it understandable and useable.</p> <p>That being said, he also had the ability to be harsh when he felt the purpose was valid.  He detested weakness and sloth to the point of being blind to the worth of individuals who may have temporarily displayed these qualities.  He demanded honesty and integrity, yet hid those lapses of his own, producing irreconcilable conflicts within himself.</p> <p>Traits which are not the least bit uncommon, but unforgivable in a leader of men.  He produced the most comprehensive system yet known for resolving an individual&#8217;s undesirable qualities, yet touted it as perfect and complete.  </p> <p>It is quite unfortunate that those who seized power over the group who was responsible for carrying on his work, are those whose main purpose were to seize power over others.  They will pass and times will change.  For the better, perhaps.  Maybe not.</p> <p>Hubbard had faults which he never overcame, and some which he did resolve.  The effects of those weaknesses that he clung to are affecting us all today.  But we are not beneath or inferior to him, nor weaker, nor blind.  We are not so superior that we can ignore his efforts.  We are bright enough to confront his perversions and embrace his discoveries.  But it is a tough road, a road which toughens.  The key is due diligence and joyful discipline.  That is where the fun begins.  And fun it can be.<br /> ARCL, Mark.</p> </div>  	</div><!-- #comment-##  -->  	<ul class="children"> 	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-christianscientology odd alt depth-8 highlander-comment" id="li-comment-330137"> 		<div id="comment-330137"> 		<div class="comment-author vcard"> 			<img alt='' src='https://2.gravatar.com/avatar/535874aa14b2cef0c4574543b07e8463?s=48&#038;d=identicon&#038;r=G' class='avatar avatar-48' height='48' width='48' /> 			<cite class="fn">christianscientology</cite>  			<span class="comment-meta commentmetadata"> 				| 				<a href="https://markrathbun.wordpress.com/2015/02/03/scientology-beliefs/#comment-330137"> 				February 14, 2015 at 4:38 pm</a> 					| 					<a class='comment-reply-link' href='/2015/02/03/scientology-beliefs/?replytocom=330137#respond' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-330137", "330137", "respond", "11823" )' aria-label='Reply to christianscientology'>Reply</a>								</span><!-- .comment-meta .commentmetadata --> 		</div><!-- .comment-author .vcard --> 		 		<div class="comment-body"><p>Thanks for your post Mark.  I find it a balanced view of L.R.H.  It is my belief that the more certain a man becomes of his truth, the more open he is to becoming a tyrant.  Perhaps it will be the uncertainty principle that will eventually save the world from fundamentalists.</p> <p>Regards<br /> Pip</p> </div>  	</div><!-- #comment-##  -->  	<ul class="children"> 	<li class="comment even depth-9 highlander-comment" id="li-comment-330499"> 		<div id="comment-330499"> 		<div class="comment-author vcard"> 			<img alt='' src='https://0.gravatar.com/avatar/f4dd23d6f380e5693407c8da3aed3807?s=48&#038;d=identicon&#038;r=G' class='avatar avatar-48' height='48' width='48' /> 			<cite class="fn">MarkNR</cite>  			<span class="comment-meta commentmetadata"> 				| 				<a href="https://markrathbun.wordpress.com/2015/02/03/scientology-beliefs/#comment-330499"> 				February 22, 2015 at 5:34 pm</a> 					| 					<a class='comment-reply-link' href='/2015/02/03/scientology-beliefs/?replytocom=330499#respond' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-330499", "330499", "respond", "11823" )' aria-label='Reply to MarkNR'>Reply</a>								</span><!-- .comment-meta .commentmetadata --> 		</div><!-- .comment-author .vcard --> 		 		<div class="comment-body"><p>Thanks Pip.</p> <p>Keep in mind that knowing with certainty and opinion and creative thought are two different things.  I know I had eggs, ham and toast with apple butter this morning.  No opinion will change that.  Why my lady decided to make that particular breakfast is a little less sure.  Some believe that fact and opinion is a gradient or gray area, but there is a solid line that can be drawn between them.  The gradient comes after the line is crossed.  The ability to recognize the difference is a large portion of what we call judgement.  </p> <p>I sometimes write my experiences as fact for all, but that is because I write shortly after my observations while they are fresh and raw.  I like to leave some things open for your evaluation and opinion.  What is true for me is not necessarily true for you, and I like to gather others thoughts and ideas.  It often leads me in an addition direction of thought.<br /> Mark</p> </div>  	</div><!-- #comment-##  -->  	<ul class="children"> 	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-vinaire odd alt depth-10 highlander-comment" id="li-comment-330517"> 		<div id="comment-330517"> 		<div class="comment-author vcard"> 			<img alt='' src='https://1.gravatar.com/avatar/1c743e7f3c77f15d38d8298be31d9780?s=48&#038;d=identicon&#038;r=G' class='avatar avatar-48' height='48' width='48' /> 			<cite class="fn"><a href='http://vinaire.wordpress.com' rel='external nofollow' class='url'>vinaire</a></cite>  			<span class="comment-meta commentmetadata"> 				| 				<a href="https://markrathbun.wordpress.com/2015/02/03/scientology-beliefs/#comment-330517"> 				February 22, 2015 at 7:38 pm</a> 					| 													</span><!-- .comment-meta .commentmetadata --> 		</div><!-- .comment-author .vcard --> 		 		<div class="comment-body"><p>Mark NR, different people have different certainties. Two certainties from different people may even be contradictory.</p> <p>All certainties are relative. This statement does not degrade any certainty we have. It simply means that one can always come up with a better certainty.</p> <p>That is how science makes progress. Einstein declared the speed of light to be a universal constant. This is a certainty for now, but there may possibly be a wider context in which the speed of light is a special case.</p> <p>Similarly, in the field of spirituality, we cannot be absolutely certain that self or soul is permanent. The phenomenon that is described as self or soul must be open to further investigation.</p> <p>There is little progress possible for a person who believes his certainties are absolute.</p> <p>One can always improve upon a certainty one has.</p> </div>  	</div><!-- #comment-##  -->  	</li><!-- #comment-## --> 	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-christianscientology even depth-10 highlander-comment" id="li-comment-330606"> 		<div id="comment-330606"> 		<div class="comment-author vcard"> 			<img alt='' src='https://2.gravatar.com/avatar/535874aa14b2cef0c4574543b07e8463?s=48&#038;d=identicon&#038;r=G' class='avatar avatar-48' height='48' width='48' /> 			<cite class="fn">christianscientology</cite>  			<span class="comment-meta commentmetadata"> 				| 				<a href="https://markrathbun.wordpress.com/2015/02/03/scientology-beliefs/#comment-330606"> 				February 24, 2015 at 8:38 am</a> 					| 													</span><!-- .comment-meta .commentmetadata --> 		</div><!-- .comment-author .vcard --> 		 		<div class="comment-body"><p>Hi Mark</p> <p>Your breakfast sounds very appetising.  Perhaps it is when ‘opinion’ and ‘creative thought’ become certainty that creative becomes destructive.</p> <p>A past Archbishop of Canterbury here in England once said “fundamentalism whether it be Christian, Jewish or Islamic is the scourge of our time” (he could have added-in Scientology there as well).</p> <p>The certainty I was thinking of is where doctrine becomes dogma, when ‘my’ truth becomes THE TRUTH.</p> <p>My thinking was influenced by this video <a href="http://www.dailymotion.com/video/x20ohne_bbc-ascent-of-man-11-knowledge-or-certainty_tv" rel="nofollow">http://www.dailymotion.com/video/x20ohne_bbc-ascent-of-man-11-knowledge-or-certainty_tv</a> which for me highlighted the difference between certainty and uncertainty, and how we used to believe that the physical universe was fixed by the laws discovered by people like Newton, and now as a result of Quantum Physics we have had to rethink things that we have taken as CERTAINTIES.  Thus making room for the idea ‘I’ might be mistaken, this is the missing factor in Scientology fundamentalism which pretty much agrees with the Christian fundamentalism.  “The Bible is the inspired word of God and is literally true” just change the word Bible for the word TECH and the word GOD for the word RON and you have a working definition of FUNDAMENTAL SCIENTOLOGY.</p> <p>Love<br /> Pip</p> </div>  	</div><!-- #comment-##  -->  	</li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## --> 	<li class="comment odd alt depth-8 highlander-comment" id="li-comment-330140"> 		<div id="comment-330140"> 		<div class="comment-author vcard"> 			<img alt='' src='https://0.gravatar.com/avatar/350d54331c090bcdace0f231815a0dd3?s=48&#038;d=identicon&#038;r=G' class='avatar avatar-48' height='48' width='48' /> 			<cite class="fn">marildi</cite>  			<span class="comment-meta commentmetadata"> 				| 				<a href="https://markrathbun.wordpress.com/2015/02/03/scientology-beliefs/#comment-330140"> 				February 14, 2015 at 5:47 pm</a> 					| 					<a class='comment-reply-link' href='/2015/02/03/scientology-beliefs/?replytocom=330140#respond' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-330140", "330140", "respond", "11823" )' aria-label='Reply to marildi'>Reply</a>								</span><!-- .comment-meta .commentmetadata --> 		</div><!-- .comment-author .vcard --> 		 		<div class="comment-body"><p>Wow, Mark. Mother appreciates it and is as much worried about us as we are for her.  She is a strong woman.  The inability to communicate is very distressing for my family more than I, but we are getting through it together.<br /> ARCL, Mark</p> </div>  	</div><!-- #comment-##  -->  	</li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## --> 	<li class="comment odd alt depth-8 highlander-comment" id="li-comment-330143"> 		<div id="comment-330143"> 		<div class="comment-author vcard"> 			<img alt='' src='https://1.gravatar.com/avatar/49ed3747454eb55c10f4beccdb4fd4f6?s=48&#038;d=identicon&#038;r=G' class='avatar avatar-48' height='48' width='48' /> 			<cite class="fn"><a href='https://markrathbun.wordpress.com/2015/02/03/scientology-beliefs/#comments' rel='external nofollow' class='url'>Conan</a></cite>  			<span class="comment-meta commentmetadata"> 				| 				<a href="https://markrathbun.wordpress.com/2015/02/03/scientology-beliefs/#comment-330143"> 				February 14, 2015 at 6:37 pm</a> 					| 					<a class='comment-reply-link' href='/2015/02/03/scientology-beliefs/?replytocom=330143#respond' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-330143", "330143", "respond", "11823" )' aria-label='Reply to Conan'>Reply</a>								</span><!-- .comment-meta .commentmetadata --> 		</div><!-- .comment-author .vcard --> 		 		<div class="comment-body"><p>Hi there OSA,<br /> &#8221; --> 	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-spyrosillusionist odd alt depth-8 highlander-comment" id="li-comment-330307"> 		<div id="comment-330307"> 		<div class="comment-author vcard"> 			<img href='/2015/02/03/scientology-beliefs/?replytocom=330307#respond' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-330307", "330307", "respond", "11823" )' aria-label='Reply to Spyros'>Reply</a>								</span><!-- .comment-meta .commentmetadata --> 		</div><!-- .comment-author .vcard --> 		 		<div class="comment-body"><p>I had a friend who -together with other friends- made a sort of a group, to chit chat and exchange knowledge about alternative therapies, as most of them had some sort of an involvement. I got invited (note that) to show them what I was into, and decided to show them a simple meditation technique that I knew. So, I told them a couple of things about it, and then asked them to do it, as my time was limited and I wanted it all to have some practical value.</p> <p>All except one at least tried. The guy who didn&#8217;t try looked pissed for some reason, and talked to others (while they were doing it) and distracted them. Because of the resulting mess (including my protests about it) that meeting didn&#8217;t go well. </p> <p>After a few days I got invited to show it again, privately to that guy who didn&#8217;t do it, but created the mess. The message was that I was incapable (among other things, I dared to protest his attitude) to deliver it, but &#8216;others&#8217; could possibly do it, and &#8216;it seemed an interesting technique afterall&#8217;.</p> </div>  	</div><!-- #comment-##  -->  	</li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## --> 	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-vinaire even depth-6 highlander-comment" id="li-comment-330053"> 		<div id="comment-330053"> 		<div class="comment-author vcard"> 			<img alt='' src='https://1.gravatar.com/avatar/1c743e7f3c77f15d38d8298be31d9780?s=48&#038;d=identicon&#038;r=G' class='avatar avatar-48' height='48' width='48' /> 			<cite class="fn"><a href='http://vinaire.wordpress.com' rel='external nofollow' class='url'>vinaire</a></cite>  			<span class="comment-meta commentmetadata"> 				| 				<a href="https://markrathbun.wordpress.com/2015/02/03/scientology-beliefs/#comment-330053"> 				February 12, 2015 at 7:23 am</a> 					| 					<a class='comment-reply-link' href='/2015/02/03/scientology-beliefs/?replytocom=330053#respond' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-330053", "330053", "respond", "11823" )' aria-label='Reply to vinaire'>Reply</a>								</span><!-- .comment-meta .commentmetadata --> 		</div><!-- .comment-author .vcard --> 		 		<div class="comment-body"><p>My conclusion is that Hubbard tried to position Scientology using the popularity of Buddhism. He defined the goals of Scientology to be similar to the goals of Buddhism; and the state of Clear to be similar to the state of Bodhi. According to him, Scientology far surpassed the results of Buddhism.</p> <p>But the truth is that through the technique of mindfulness Buddha could see that the self was illusory, and he took steps to help others transcend that illusion. However, Hubbard and Scientology went in the opposite direction making the empowering of individuality to be its goal. These two goals are completely opposite of each other. Please see,</p> <p><a href="http://vinaire.me/2013/09/24/hubbard-scientology-and-buddhism/" rel="nofollow"><b>Hubbard, Scientology and Buddhism</b></a><br /> .</p> </div>  	</div><!-- #comment-##  -->  	<ul class="children"> 	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-spyrosillusionist odd alt depth-7 highlander-comment" id="li-comment-330088"> 		<div id="comment-330088"> 		<div class="comment-author vcard"> 			<img alt='' src='https://1.gravatar.com/avatar/1e3a3898eb06ac9bec55d9581e9d1dd4?s=48&#038;d=identicon&#038;r=G' class='avatar avatar-48' height='48' width='48' /> 			<cite class="fn"><a href='http://spyrosillusionist.wordpress.com' rel='external nofollow' class='url'>Spyros</a></cite>  			<span class="comment-meta commentmetadata"> 				| 				<a href="https://markrathbun.wordpress.com/2015/02/03/scientology-beliefs/#comment-330088"> 				February 13, 2015 at 11:12 am</a> 					| 					<a class='comment-reply-link' href='/2015/02/03/scientology-beliefs/?replytocom=330088#respond' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-330088", "330088", "respond", "11823" )' aria-label='Reply to Spyros'>Reply</a>								</span><!-- .comment-meta .commentmetadata --> 		</div><!-- .comment-author .vcard --> 		 		<div class="comment-body"><p>Vinaire, I have long understood what you try to say, and I have long answered to you.
